Given a bounded linear operator $A\in{\mathbb B}({\cal K})$, a subset $\Delta\subset{\mathbb C}$ is called separating if the boundary $\partial\Delta$ has no intersection with the spectrum $\sigma(A)$ of $A$. For a separating set $\Delta\subset{\mathbb C}$ for $A$, let $P_\Delta(A)$ denote the associated Riesz spectral projection of $A$. Further let us set ${\cal E}_\Delta(A)={\mbox{\rm Ran}}(P_\Delta(A))$ and ${\cal F}_\Delta(A)={\mbox{\rm Ker}}(P_\Delta(A))$. If $\Delta=\{\lambda\}$, we also write $P_\lambda(A)$, ${\cal E}_\lambda(A)$ and ${\cal F}_\lambda(A)$. If it is clear from the context, the argument $A$ will be dropped. General properties of Riesz projections can be found in \cite{Kat} or the appendix of \cite{SB}. Proofs of the following facts can be found in \cite{Bog,AI,SB}. 


 
\begin{proposi}
\label{prop-basicprops} Let $({\cal K},{J} )$ be a Krein space.

\begin{enumerate}[{\rm (i)}] 

\item ${\mathbb U}({\cal K},{J} )$ is a group under composition.


\item ${\mathbb H}({\cal K},{J} )$ is a ${\mathbb R}$-linear space.

\item For $H\in {\mathbb H}({\cal K},{J} )$, one has $\exp(\imath \,tH)\in {\mathbb U}({\cal K},{J} )$ for all $t\in{\mathbb R}$.

\item For $T\in {\mathbb U}({\cal K},{J} )$ one has the reflection property $\overline{\sigma(T)}=\sigma(T)^{-1}$ around ${\mathbb S}^1$. 

\item For $H\in {\mathbb H}({\cal K},{J} )$ one has the reflection property $\overline{\sigma(H)}=\sigma(H)$ w.r.t. the real axis.

\item For a separating subset $\Delta$ for $T\in {\mathbb U}({\cal K},{J} )$, one has $P_\Delta(T)^*={J} P_{(\overline{\Delta})^{-1}}(T){J} $.

\item For a separating subset $\Delta$ for $H\in {\mathbb H}({\cal K},{J} )$, one has $P_\Delta(H)^*={J} P_{\overline{\Delta}}(H){J} $.

\item For $T\in {\mathbb U}({\cal K},{J} )$ and $\lambda\in\sigma(T)\cap{\mathbb S}^1$ a discrete (isolated and of finite multiplicity) eigenvalue,  the hermitian form ${J}  |_{{\cal E}_\lambda(T)}$  is non-degenerate.

\item For $H\in {\mathbb H}({\cal K},{J} )$ and $\lambda\in\sigma(H)\cap{\mathbb R}$ is a discrete eigenvalue,  the hermitian form ${J}  |_{{\cal E}_\lambda(H)}$  is non-degenerate.

\end{enumerate}
\end{proposi}


By item (iii) the ${J} $-hermitian can be seen as the Lie algebra of ${\mathbb U}({\cal K},{J} )$. An alternative convention is to require $e^{tB}\in{\mathbb U}({\cal K},{J} )$ for all $t\in{\mathbb R}$, which then implies ${J} B^* =-B{J}$ and thus $\sigma(B)=-\overline{\sigma(B)}$. In our opinion this is less practical for the spectral analysis carried out in the present work.

For eigenvalues off the unit circle the inertia are defined to be $0$. Eigenvalues are called indefinite (sometimes also of mixed signature) if both $\nu_\pm(\lambda,T)$  are non-vanishing, otherwise they are called definite or ${J}$-definite. The Krein signature of $\lambda$ is defined as

\section{Unbounded $J$-isometric to $J$-selfadjoint operators}
\label{sec-unbounded}

In this section, we briefly analyze unbounded operators on a Krein space which satisfy a Fredholm property. Real symmetries are not dealt with, as the analysis of Section~\ref{sec-realStruc} transposes directly.


\begin{defini}[\cite{Bog}]  Let $({\cal K},J)$ be a Krein space.

\begin{enumerate}[{\rm (i)}]

\item A closed densely defined operator $T$ with domain ${\cal D}(T)\subset{\cal K}$ is called $J$-isometric if for all $\phi,\psi\in{\cal D}(T)$ one has $\phi^*J\psi=(T\phi)^*J(T\psi)$.

\item An  operator $A$ with domain ${\cal D}(A)\subset{\cal K}$ is called $J$-symmetric if for all $\phi,\psi\in{\cal D}(A)$ one has $\phi^*J(A\psi)=(A\phi)^*J\psi$.

\item A closed densely defined operator $H$ on ${\cal K}$ is called $J$-selfadjoint if $H=JH^*J$ holds on the domain ${\cal D}(H)=J{\cal D}(H^*)$.

\item  The set of $J$-isometric operators is denoted by ${\mathbb I}({\cal K},J)$.

\item  The set of $J$-selfadjoint operators is denoted by ${\mathbb S}({\cal K},J)$.

\end{enumerate}

\end{defini}




Let us point to one difference w.r.t. \cite{Bog}, namely here we require $J$-isometric operators to be densely defined and closed. An everywhere defined $J$-isometry is a $J$-unitary,  and an everywhere defined $J$-selfadjoint is $J$-hermitian. Furthermore, every $J$-selfadjoint operator is $J$-symmetric, and an everywhere defined $J$-symmetric operator is $J$-selfadjoint. The sets  ${\mathbb I}({\cal K},J)$ and ${\mathbb S}({\cal K},J)$ are endowed with the gap topology \cite{Kat}. Convergence in the gap topology is equivalent to convergence of the resolvent sets and the norm of the resolvents \cite[IV.2.25]{Kat}, and on the subset of bounded operators it coincides with the norm topology. It is now possible to work with Riesz projections and Krein signatures of isolated eigenvalues as before. Hence, one can introduce the set ${\mathbb G}{\mathbb I}({\cal K},J)$ of essentially ${\mathbb S}^1$-gapped $J$-isometries just as in Definition~\ref{def-essS1}, and the set ${\mathbb G}{\mathbb S}({\cal K},J)$ of essentially ${\mathbb R}$-gapped $J$-selfadjoint as in Definition~\ref{def-essR}. For both of these sets the signature can be defined as above. This is a homotopy invariant on ${\mathbb G}{\mathbb I}({\cal K},J)$ and ${\mathbb G}{\mathbb S}({\cal K},J)$ in the sense that ${\mbox{\rm Sig}}$ is constant for continuous paths in ${\mathbb G}{\mathbb I}({\cal K},J)$ and ${\mathbb G}{\mathbb S}({\cal K},J)$ w.r.t. the gap topology.  The proof of this claim is based on the results of Section IV.3.5 of \cite{Kat} which show that isolated eigenvalues vary continuously in the gap topology. Therefore, all results of Krein collision theory for bounded operators transpose to the unbounded cases. Finally,  following Definition~\ref{def-essS1}, it is also possible to define the set ${\mathbb F}{\mathbb I}({\cal K},J)$ of ${\mathbb S}^1$-Fredholm $J$-isometries and the set ${\mathbb F}{\mathbb S}({\cal K},J)$ of ${\mathbb R}$-Fredholm $J$-selfadjoints. Let us show by an explicit example that there are some surprises for unbounded $J$-selfadjoint operators.

\vspace{.2cm}

\noindent {\bf Example} Section~6.4 of \cite{SB} constructs a loop $t\in[0,2\pi)\mapsto T_t=Te^{\imath tK}$ of $J$-unitary ${\mathbb S}^1$-Fredholm operators from a given $J$-unitary $T$ and compact $J$-selfadjoint operator $K=JK^*J$, with the property that $\sigma(T_t)=r\,{\mathbb S}^1\cup r^{-1}{\mathbb S}^1$ for some $r\in(0,1)$ and all $t$ but for two special values $t=\frac{\pi}{2},\frac{3\pi}{2}$; for these special values the annulus $\{z\in{\mathbb C}\,:\,r<|z|<r^{-1}\}$ completely fills with point spectrum. Let us now consider the Cayley transform $C_{z,\zeta}^{-1}(T_t)$ of this loop. This is a loop inside the unbouned $J$-selfadjoint operators satisfying the ${\mathbb R}$-Fredholm property. However, at the above special values, the whole real axis belongs to the point spectrum of these operators. Hence we conclude that ${\mathbb G}{\mathbb S}({\cal K},J)$ is a proper subset of ${\mathbb F}{\mathbb S}({\cal K},J)$. 
\hfill $\diamond$



\vspace{.2cm}

Next let us point out that the statements of Proposition~\ref{prop-Cayley} can be generalized as follows \cite{Bog}: for $z\in\rho(H)$ of a $J$-selfadjoint operator, $C_{z,\zeta}(H)$ is $J$-unitary; if one only requires $z\not\in\sigma_p(H)$ for a $J$-selfadjoint operator $H$,  it is still possible to define $C_{z,\zeta}(H)$ as $J$-isometric operator. Similarly, if $z\in\rho(T)$ of a $J$-isometric operator $T$, then $C_{z,\zeta}^{-1}(T)$ is $J$-hermitian; and if  $\zeta\not\in\sigma_p(T)$ for a $J$-isometric operator $T$, then $C_{z,\zeta}^{-1}(T)$ is a $J$-selfadjoint operator.  Combining these properties with the homotopy arguments in the proof of Theorem~\ref{theo-connected} one can possibly prove the following

\vspace{.2cm}

\noindent {\bf Conjecture:}  The set ${\mathbb G}{\mathbb I}_n({\cal K},J)=\{T\in {\mathbb G}{\mathbb I}({\cal K},J)\,:\,{\mbox{\rm Sig}}(T)=n\}$ is connected.
